prompt: Procedures: Bronchoscopy, Stent Placement (Aero 14x30 mm, 14x40 mm), Trach Exchange. Diagnosis: BPF post-esophagectomy. Indication: 2.0 cm fistula in mid-left mainstem. Complication: Stent migration requiring revision. Disposition: ICU.
completion:
NOTE_ID: note_001
DATE OF PROCEDURE: January 12

INDICATION FOR OPERATION
The patient is a 77-year-old male who presents with a broncho-esophageal (anastomosis) fistula s/p Ivor Lewis Esophagostomy. The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail. The patient wished to proceed and informed consent was obtained.

CONSENT
Obtained before the procedure. Indications, potential complications, and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate. Consent was signed and witnessed by an assisting medical professional.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Broncho-esophageal (anastomosis) fistula s/p Ivor Lewis Esophagostomy

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Broncho-esophageal (anastomosis) fistula s/p Ivor Lewis Esophagostomy
Status post occlusive left mainstem stent placement

PROCEDURE
Flexible bronchoscopy via tracheostomy
Endobronchial biopsy (multiple sites)
Self-expandable airway stent placement (Aero)
Fluoroscopy guidance
Tracheostomy tube exchange (secondary to stent removal)

ATTENDING: Dr. Chen

ANESTHESIA: General Anesthesia

MONITORING
Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and blood pressure were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer throughout the procedure.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL
After induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed confirming patient identity, planned procedures, and laterality. Relevant procedural images were saved to the medical record.

Airway Inspection
The flexible bronchoscope was passed through the patient's tracheostomy tube and into the airways. The trachea was normal. Purulent secretions were seen throughout the airways and were suctioned.

Right Lung: Inspection showed multiple small endobronchial nodular lesions concerning for airway metastasis.
Left Lung: A 2.0 cm fistula was identified at the medial aspect of the posterior wall of the mid-left mainstem. Distally, multiple small endobronchial lesions were noted with an appearance suggestive of malignancy.

Endobronchial Biopsy
Multiple nodules from the left and right side were biopsied with flexible forceps. Samples were placed in formalin.

Stent Placement
The length of the fistula was measured. A Jagwire was inserted through the flexible bronchoscope past the fistula within the left mainstem. Using fluoroscopy, the proximal and distal edges of the target area were marked with radiopaque markers (paper clips) taped to the patient’s chest wall. The flexible bronchoscope was removed.

An Aero 14x30 mm stent was advanced over the guidewire and positioned based on the external markers under fluoroscopic observation. The stent was deployed slightly proximally, with the distal edge just covering the fistula.

A second 14x40 mm Aero stent was placed into the previously placed stent to better cover the obstruction. Upon inspection, the originally placed stent (14x30 mm) was noted to have been pushed distally by the second stent, obstructing the orifice of the left upper and lower lobes.

Stent Revision and Tracheostomy Exchange
The 14x40 mm stent was removed by grasping the proximal edge with forceps. The stent could not be retracted through the tracheostomy tube.

Tracheostomy Exchange: The tracheostomy tube was removed. The stent was pulled through the stoma. The tracheostomy tube was then re-inserted over a bronchoscope and re-attached to the ventilator.

Final Positioning
The remaining 14x30 mm Aero fully covered self-expandable metallic stent was retracted into proper position (within the left mainstem covering the fistula) using forceps. Final inspection demonstrated satisfactory positioning. The bronchoscope was removed.

IMPRESSION / PLAN
Transfer back to ICU.
Await tissue diagnosis from biopsied endobronchial nodules.
Obtain post-procedure chest imaging.
Q6H saline nebulizers along with ensuring oxygen is humidified to avoid mucous impaction and obstruction of stent.

prompt: stent placement for fistula. 62 M. used aero 14x30 mm and 12x40 mm. issue with migration. removed the 12x40 mm (had to take out trach) and fixed the 14x30 mm. biopsies taken. Dr. Al-Fayed.

The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail. The patient wished to proceed and informed consent was obtained.

CONSENT
Obtained before the procedure. Indications, potential complications, and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate. Consent was signed and witnessed by an assisting medical professional.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Broncho-esophageal (anastomosis) fistula s/p Ivor Lewis Esophagostomy

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Broncho-esophageal (anastomosis) fistula s/p Ivor Lewis Esophagostomy
Status post occlusive left mainstem stent placement

PROCEDURE
Flexible bronchoscopy via tracheostomy
Endobronchial biopsy (multiple sites)
Self-expandable airway stent placement (Aero)
Fluoroscopy guidance
Tracheostomy tube exchange (secondary to stent removal)

ATTENDING: Dr. Miller

ANESTHESIA: General Anesthesia

MONITORING
Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and blood pressure were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer throughout the procedure.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL
After induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed confirming patient identity, planned procedures, and laterality. Relevant procedural images were saved to the medical record.

Airway Inspection
The flexible bronchoscope was passed through the patient's tracheostomy tube and into the airways. The trachea was normal. Blood-tinged secretions were seen throughout the airways and were suctioned.

Right Lung: Inspection showed multiple small endobronchial nodular lesions concerning for airway metastasis.
Left Lung: A 1.0 cm fistula was identified at the medial aspect of the posterior wall of the mid-left mainstem. Distally, multiple small endobronchial lesions were noted with an appearance suggestive of malignancy.

Endobronchial Biopsy
Multiple nodules from the left and right side were biopsied with flexible forceps. Samples were placed in formalin.

Stent Placement
The length of the fistula was measured. A Jagwire was inserted through the flexible bronchoscope past the fistula within the left mainstem. Using fluoroscopy, the proximal and distal edges of the target area were marked with radiopaque markers (paper clips) taped to the patient’s chest wall. The flexible bronchoscope was removed.

An Aero 12x30 mm stent was advanced over the guidewire and positioned based on the external markers under fluoroscopic observation. The stent was deployed slightly proximally, with the distal edge just covering the fistula.

A second 14x40 mm Aero stent was placed into the previously placed stent to better cover the obstruction. Upon inspection, the originally placed stent (12x30 mm) was noted to have been pushed distally by the second stent, obstructing the orifice of the left upper and lower lobes.

Stent Revision and Tracheostomy Exchange
The 14x40 mm stent was removed by grasping the proximal edge with forceps. The stent could not be retracted through the tracheostomy tube.

Tracheostomy Exchange: The tracheostomy tube was removed. The stent was pulled through the stoma. The tracheostomy tube was then re-inserted over a bronchoscope and re-attached to the ventilator.

Final Positioning
The remaining 12x30 mm Aero fully covered self-expandable metallic stent was retracted into proper position (within the left mainstem covering the fistula) using forceps. Final inspection demonstrated satisfactory positioning. The bronchoscope was removed.

IMPRESSION / PLAN
Transfer back to ICU.
Await tissue diagnosis from biopsied endobronchial nodules.
Obtain post-procedure chest imaging.
BID saline nebulizers along with ensuring oxygen is humidified to avoid mucous impaction and obstruction of stent.

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Broncho-esophageal (anastomosis) fistula s/p Ivor Lewis Esophagostomy
Status post occlusive left mainstem stent placement

PROCEDURE
Flexible bronchoscopy via tracheostomy
Endobronchial biopsy (multiple sites)
Self-expandable airway stent placement (Aero)
Fluoroscopy guidance
Tracheostomy tube exchange (secondary to stent removal)

ATTENDING: Dr. Smith

ANESTHESIA: General Anesthesia

MONITORING
Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and blood pressure were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer throughout the procedure.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL
After induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed confirming patient identity, planned procedures, and laterality. Relevant procedural images were saved to the medical record.

Airway Inspection
The flexible bronchoscope was passed through the patient's tracheostomy tube and into the airways. The trachea was normal. Thick mucoid secretions were seen throughout the airways and were suctioned.

Right Lung: Inspection showed multiple small endobronchial nodular lesions concerning for airway metastasis.
Left Lung: A 1.0 cm fistula was identified at the medial aspect of the posterior wall of the proximal left mainstem. Distally, multiple small endobronchial lesions were noted with an appearance suggestive of malignancy.

Endobronchial Biopsy
Multiple nodules from the left and right side were biopsied with flexible forceps. Samples were placed in formalin.

Stent Placement
The length of the fistula was measured. A Jagwire was inserted through the flexible bronchoscope past the fistula within the left mainstem. Using fluoroscopy, the proximal and distal edges of the target area were marked with radiopaque markers (paper clips) taped to the patient’s chest wall. The flexible bronchoscope was removed.

An Aero 14x30 mm stent was advanced over the guidewire and positioned based on the external markers under fluoroscopic observation. The stent was deployed slightly proximally, with the distal edge just covering the fistula.

A second 12x40 mm Aero stent was placed into the previously placed stent to better cover the obstruction. Upon inspection, the originally placed stent (14x30 mm) was noted to have been pushed distally by the second stent, obstructing the orifice of the left upper and lower lobes.

Stent Revision and Tracheostomy Exchange
The 12x40 mm stent was removed by grasping the proximal edge with forceps. The stent could not be retracted through the tracheostomy tube.

Tracheostomy Exchange: The tracheostomy tube was removed. The stent was pulled through the stoma. The tracheostomy tube was then re-inserted over a bronchoscope and re-attached to the ventilator.

Final Positioning
The remaining 14x30 mm Aero fully covered self-expandable metallic stent was retracted into proper position (within the left mainstem covering the fistula) using forceps. Final inspection demonstrated satisfactory positioning. The bronchoscope was removed.

IMPRESSION / PLAN
Transfer back to ICU.
Await tissue diagnosis from biopsied endobronchial nodules.
Obtain post-procedure chest imaging.
TID saline nebulizers along with ensuring oxygen is humidified to avoid mucous impaction and obstruction of stent.
